ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Survey of post-colonial literature, archival source analysis, essay writing

Prof. Richards really helped me improve my close-reading skills, not just through feedback but also with specific strategies taught in class. I also learned so much about the non-western world, and was so glad to be exposed to non-western literature. Prof. Richards did a wonderful job of justifying each work's identity within the curriculum and of describing its influence and importance, not just through her knowledge but with her presentations.
Close reading and application of that reading to a text as a whole.
Improved style and structure of essay writing, improved close reading skills, more comfortable accessing primary sources and doing research for a paper
I improved my essay-writing abilities, particularly in that I learned to combine literary analysis with historical research and archival analysis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: wonderful professor, enriching in-class discussions, helped improve my writing
Weaknesses: I wasn't a huge fan of some of the books we read  I would have preferred a greater focus on contemporary texts, as I felt like I got the most out of those (Exit West and Nervous Conditions were incredible!)

It was more structured than the American Literature course, and that really helped, especially to introduce its students to something as broad as world anglophone literatures. It also really helps you develop as a writer, especially as a close-reader.

I think there's just too much reading. I had to look up summaries many times, not because I didn't want to read but because I simply didn't have enough time to read 300-400 pages a week for one class. Taking out one or two books would be enough.

Strengths: Good and interesting variation of novels, small seminar makes it easy to stay engaged and create strong classroom community, lots of intellectual freedom within discussions and within papers, Professor Richards is absolutely wonderful
Weaknesses: Reading a novel per week is a very fast pace so sometimes you don't get to analyze each novel as in-depth as would be helpful
Im not sure how I feel about the syllabus and the general structure/ethos of the course. It seems a bit cobbled together, and its intent is muddled.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're interested in post-colonial literature, then yes. The class is well organized and Professor Richards is one of the kindest professors I've ever had!
Yes, absolutely, especially to English majors. It's a very efficient way to learn to write and analyze literature.
Yes, especially with Professor Richards! The reading material was really engaging, one of my favorite English courses Ive taken so far at Yale.

If you like English classes, then yes! Out of the foundational English courses I've taken, this one has definitely been my favorite. The novels are very interesting, and class discussions were productive and helpful toward understanding. Although the pace of the class is quite fast with the heavy reading load (a novel per week, about 200 pages), the papers are not terribly difficult or long, so I found that the workload wasn't terrible overall. The class mainly focuses on close reading and coming up with your own interpretations of a passage/text, and I really enjoyed having this freedom. I do think my very positive experience with the course has everything to do with Professor Richards, who runs by far the best seminar at Yale that I have ever been a part of. Professor Richards comes into class every day well-prepared, organized, and ready to teach, and it was always clear that they had put a lot of effort into making sure class has a nice mixture of instruction, small group work, and guided discussion, which made class engaging for the entire hour and fifteen minutes. If you take this course, take it with Professor Richards!
I would certainly recommend professor Richards, but Im not certain that Id recommend ENGL 128 to anyone but an English Major.
